title: (85182) 1991 AQ
text:
(85182) 1991 AQ, provisional designation , is a stony <a href="asteroid">asteroid</a> on a highly eccentric orbit, classified as <a href="near-Earth%20object">near-Earth object</a> and <a href="potentially%20hazardous%20asteroid">potentially hazardous asteroid</a> of the <a href="Apollo%20asteroid">Apollo group</a>, approximately in diameter. It was discovered on 14 January 1991, by American astronomer <a href="Eleanor%20Helin">Eleanor Helin</a> at the <a href="Palomar%20Observatory">Palomar Observatory</a> in California. Based on its brightness variation of 0.69 <a href="Magnitude%20%28astronomy%29">magnitude</a>, this <a href="Q-type%20asteroid">Q-type asteroid</a> is likely elongated. It belongs to the small group of potentially hazardous asteroids larger than one kilometer.
Orbit and classification.
 is a member of the <a href="Earth-crossing%20asteroid">Earth-crossing</a> class of <a href="Apollo%20asteroid">Apollo asteroid</a>s, the largest group of <a href="near-Earth%20object">near-Earth object</a>s with approximately 10 thousand known members. It is also a <a href="Venus-crosser">Venus-</a> and <a href="Mars-crosser">Mars-crosser</a> due to its extreme <a href="perihelion%20and%20aphelion">perihelion and aphelion</a>, respectively.
It orbits the Sun at a distance of 0.5–3.9 <a href="Astronomical%20unit">AU</a> once every 3 years and 4 months (1,210 days; <a href="semi-major%20axis">semi-major axis</a> of 2.22 AU). Its orbit has a high <a href="orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricity</a> of 0.78 and an <a href="orbital%20inclination">inclination</a> of 3<a href="Degree%20%28angle%29">°</a> with respect to the <a href="ecliptic">ecliptic</a>. The body's <a href="observation%20arc">observation arc</a> begins with its official discovery observation at Palomar in 1991.
Close approaches.
The asteroid has currently an Earth <a href="minimum%20orbital%20intersection%20distance">minimum orbital intersection distance</a> of , which corresponds to 6.4 <a href="Lunar%20distance%20%28astronomy%29">lunar distances</a> and makes it a <a href="potentially%20hazardous%20asteroid">potentially hazardous asteroid</a> due to its notably large size. In 1991 and 1994, it approached Earth at a nominal distance of . The asteroids closest encounter with Earth is projected to occur on 27 January 2130, at a distance of only "(see table)". It also makes close encounters to <a href="Mercury%20%28planet%29">Mercury</a>, <a href="Venus">Venus</a>, <a href="Mars">Mars</a> and <a href="Jupiter">Jupiter</a>.
Physical characteristics.
In the <a href="Tholen%20classification">Tholen classification</a>, this object is an uncommon <a href="Q-type%20asteroid">Q-type asteroid</a>, that falls into the larger stony <a href="S-type%20asteroid">S-complex</a>. As of 2018, no rotational <a href="lightcurve">lightcurve</a> of this asteroid has been obtained from <a href="Photometry%20%28astronomy%29">photometric</a> observations. The body's <a href="rotation%20period">rotation period</a>, <a href="Poles%20of%20astronomical%20bodies">pole</a> and shape remain unknown. It has a brightness variation of 0.69 <a href="Magnitude%20%28astronomy%29">magnitude</a>, indicative for an elongated, non-spherical shape.
Diameter and albedo.
According to the survey carried out by the <a href="NEOWISE">NEOWISE</a> mission of NASA's <a href="Wide-field%20Infrared%20Survey%20Explorer">Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</a>, this asteroid measures 1.1 kilometers in diameter and its surface has an <a href="astronomical%20albedo">albedo</a> of 0.242. The "Collaborative Asteroid Lightcurve Link" assumes an albedo of 0.18 and derives a diameter of 1.14 kilometers based on an <a href="absolute%20magnitude">absolute magnitude</a> of 17.20.
Numbering and naming.
This <a href="minor%20planet">minor planet</a> was <a href="Minor%20planet%20designation">numbered</a> by the <a href="Minor%20Planet%20Center">Minor Planet Center</a> on 30 August 2004 (). As of 2018, it has not been <a href="List%20of%20named%20minor%20planets%20%28alphabetical%29">named</a>.
